COURSE DESCRIPTION ：
This course aims to provide  the participants with basic and practical knowledge in the structure and function of the financial system. We examine the  role, objectives and function of financial  regulation,  the evolving role of central banking and monetary policy and the implications and consequences on financial institutions and markets. Throughout the course we link prevalent economic theories to market realities. Topics covered include: the fundamentals  of interest rates and  basic pricing  of financial assets,  including basic concepts such as  cash flows, the time value of money and  the risk-return  tradeoff; the  structure  and  function of the financial system, the  role and the types of  financial institutions and financial intermediaries; the goals of financial and banking regulations, the organization of central banks and the role of monetary policy. There will be a strong focus on financial institutions, understanding the role that the different types of firms play and how they interact. This course does NOT go into details of various markets for stocks, bonds and other securities, which are covered in other finance courses.

reviews.author: Mango Pudding
reviews.title: Great intro to financial markets for those without prior knowledge
reviews.comment_content:
1. Intro, an overview of financial markets
- Financial statements, financial system, financial markets, players of FMs, classification of FMs
2. Foundations of interest rates [Calculation topic]
- Discounted cash flow concept (Present and future value)
- Perpetuities, annuities, bonds and short-term debt instrument calculations
3. Financial intermediation, types of financial intermediaries
4. Sell-side: Commercial banks
- Bank management: Liquidity, asset, liability and capital management
- Types of risk in banking, bank performance, bank organisation, issues in banking
5. Sell-side: Investment banking
6. Fundamentals of pricing and valuation [Calculation topic]
- Equity valuation, dividend-discount model DDM
7. Buy-side: Institutional investors and other financial intermediaries
- Insurance, pension and retirement funds, mutual funds, exchange-traded funds ETFs
8. Buy-side: Alternatives
- Sovereign wealth funds SWFs, angel investors, venture capital, private equity, hedge fund
9. Financial & Banking regulation (If time allows, which we didn't teach)
10. Central banking & Monetary policy (If time allows, which we didn't teach)

A lot of slides and words for each topic, but if you follow along in class, you will be fine. Also, since it is open notes, you just need to make sure to have well-organised notes that you can search through quickly.

As someone without prior knowledge of or any interest in any of these topics, the content is not challenging and even is useful in understanding financial events occurring globally.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor loves interacting with students and would answer questions promptly even if those are slightly off-track or in-depth. Sometimes she relates her past stories in the financial sector to the current topic. Always tries to keep the lecture interesting.

Also, be sure to note down the sidenotes taught that could be conducive to understanding (and just in case those are assessed, which usually aren't).

One good thing is that you are allowed to bring your devices and refer to the lecture notes during the mid-term exam and final exam, so you don't have to memorize everything. However, the topics covered in every quiz/exam involve hundreds of pages and time is limited, so you have to familiarize yourself with the lecture notes in order to search for the answers asap during quizzes/exams. If you don't have "sources" but you want to get a good grade, do spare some time to watch her lecture videos and copy down everything she said so that you won't feel shocked when something that is not mentioned in the lecture notes appears in the quizzes/exams.

reviews.comment_content:
Interest rates, DCF, Financial Institutions (Both Buy and Sell-Side), Asset Pricing, insurance, and various banking regulation and monetary policy. Should be noted that this course is more about the fundamentals of financial markets and the systems by which markets are linked and facilitated. This isn't the course you take to learn how to trade stocks. That's other courses.

Good split between concepts but also formulas and math. I suppose it varies year to year but sometimes she shared important financial or business news with us and discussed current events. Not graded ofcs.

Some stuff is more interesting than others but that's a personal preference. The only potential negative for content is that there's quite a lot to cover.

Will give u feedback or help on group assignments before you hand it in which is great.

The grading is actually pretty fair and you're allowed to do a paper review to see what you did wrong. You just have to book it with Prof and her TA. If your IPRS doesn't work in a class (there's IPRS in almost all classes) message the TA Benson immediately. They are understanding.
reviews.comment_workload:
IPRS - IPRS in class almost every lesson, you don't have to get the correct answer but you must answer. She will explain the answer.

Chat/Breakout Room - We only had two breakout rooms. She tells u to go discuss something then come back and one person per group share with the class. If your group did nothing pray u can bs or just rephrase what the other groups said. Unless your group 1 in which case good luck. For chat don't ask stupid stupid things or the questions where you're actually showing off your financial knowledge. Prof and TA will sense it from a mile away. Just IPRS is fine for participation points. IPRS questions actually show up again in the quizzes.

Quizzes & Exam - Time limit (hour to hour and a half if i remember correctly) TF, MCQ and fill ins. There are a lot more T/F and MCQ then fill ins but the fill ins are worth a lot of points and are math questions. She provides a spreadsheet for the formula so the trick is figuring out from the word question which formula to use. Open Book quiz.

A lot of the questions are actually only quizzes online.  

Groupwork - Two group projects. One was to record a presentation and send and another was to find news videos corresponding to a prompt. These are early in the class so ask her questions and get her to check before the hand in. You can ask if the article link you chose seems ok. Take the opportunity of her kindness in this matter.Also, a lot less work than it sounds like.

reviews.title: High mean with lot of stuff to recite
reviews.comment_content:
JUST A LOT OF HARD FACTS TO RECITE!

This course gives you an overview on financial market such as overview on commercial & investment banks, interests rate calculations and financial regulations. This course can give you a brief overview on what finance is about, but I feel like there are too much stuff to recite (Expect >70 slides per chapter) and it gets kinda boring. It doesn't matter whether you've studies BAFS in DSE as almost all chapters are new stuff.

===Content=== (* involves calculation)
1. Introduction to Financial Markets
*2. Foundations of Interest Rates I
*3. Foundations of Interest Rates II
4. Financial Intermediation
5. The Sell Side: Commercial Banks
6. The Sell Side: Investment Banks
----Mid Term (Ch. 1~6 [1st part])----
7. The Buy Side: Traditional Investors
*8. Stock Valuation
9. The Shadow Market: Alternative Investors
10. Financial Regulations
----Final Exam (Ch. 6 [2nd part] ~10)----

===General Comments===
Basically this course introduces what financial services do, like banks, hedge funds, mutual funds and etc. The professor didn't go too deep into those and introduces us some common technical jargon.

However, I don't like that this course needs so much memorization! Each chapter has around 20~40 slides that have key points to remember, and sometimes we need to recite BORING stuff like which regulation does what thing. Would love to see more calculation in this course rather than factual stuff.

I would recommend this course to business students because the calculation concepts will be taught again in FINA2303 so it's good to have some background knowledge
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor tries to make the lesson atmosphere relaxed and fun. She loves asking students questions and run around in the lecture hall to stuff microphone to students.

I think she's fine when explaining concepts. She would give basic explanation to technical terms and make additional notes. What I don't like about her is that she only explains HALF of the technical jargon! It's very easy to get lost in lessons as she skip lecture slides so fast that I cannot digest. You need to look out the remaining jargon in Investopedia mainly

She also loves to go off-topic in lessons to introduce you current issues in finance or a scenario problem. This gives you some more insight, but personally I would love her explain the jargon clearer instead. It's kinda boring when she does that.
reviews.comment_grading:
THE MEAN IS SO FREAKING HIGH!
A LOT of students are from Year 2~3 wanting to get good grades so it's very difficult for Year 1 students to compete. This makes the mean so freaking high too :(

===Assessment===
Participation through iPRS - 5%
4 Online Canvas quizzes - 20% (5% each)
Group Assessment - 10%
Mid-Term - 30%
Final - 35%

===My Scores===
Quiz 1: 92/100
Quiz 2: 89/100
Quiz 3: 100/100
Quiz 4: 100/100
Mid-Term: 76/100 [Mean: 72.74  ;  SD: 12.74  ;  Median: 74]
Final: ?? (They didn't give us the marks)
-----
Final Grade: B+

I feel like the mean is super high (as seen from mid-terms). If you do slightly above mean then B range for you. Very hard to get A range if your mid-term isn't above 1 SD

===PRS===
She forces you to attend the lessons by asking 4~5 PRS questions per lecture. Sometimes the PRS answers are written lecture notes (Especially calculation) and still some will get wrong

===Online Quiz===
Professor will give total of 4 quizzes in Canvas (30 minutes each). Some questions are in PRS and some questions ask you topics that have NEVER appeared in notes! They just copy last semester's question so it would be great if you have source :P

===Mid-Term & Final===
RECITE THE CANVAS QUIZ QUESTIONS! 40% of the questions are straight up copied from the quizzes! Both papers are all MC questions. Sometimes they ask you very detailed.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is fine. It isn't too demanding

===Studying quiz and exams===
Quiz shouldn't be a problem if you have sources lol (If you have them then you don't need to study for quiz). Just take some time reciting the boring facts and constantly going to Investopedia

===Group Projects===
You need to join a group and do two tasks. First one is to find a news article and a video related to current financial issues. Second one is a super short financial news presentation. They fixed the time limit to be under 5 minutes so every person only needs to read a few lines.
